awd_titl_txt: Hotplate Precipitation and Wind Measurement Improvement
awd_abstract_narration:
Precipitation is a vital element of the Earth system. Where and when it occurs, and in what amount, affects the planning of individuals, communities, regions, and nations. For these reasons, there is clear justification for measuring precipitation. From a scientific perspective, the measurement of precipitation is important for understanding Earth's atmospheric, hydrological, and energy cycles. Improved weather forecasts and improved weather notification are two societal benefits that stem from making, analyzing, and improving precipitation measurements. In this project, multiple versions of a relatively new precipitation measurement system, the hotplate gauge, are investigated.  Collocated deployment of multiple hotplates during precipitation events and analysis of data from these systems and events, is the basis of the research. The goal is to enhance scientific confidence in hotplate measurements of precipitation and wind speed.

A significant problem in hydrometeorology is quantitative precipitation estimation (QPE). The foundation of QPE is measurements of precipitation made with precipitation gauges. In the case of snowfall, measurements obtained from weighing gauges can be compromised by gauge capping, delay in registration of snowfall, and by wind-induced snow particle undercatch. For each of these, bias on the order of a factor of two is consistent with present understanding. This project extends a new paradigm in ground-based measurement of snowfall. The basis is the hotplate technology developed by the National Center for Atmospheric Research and the Desert Research Institute. Because a hotplate's upward- and downward-facing surfaces are maintained at 70 degrees Celsius, this type of precipitation system is immune to capping and delay errors and its measurement of wind speed is not compromised by icing. Since 2005, a private company has been licensed to market the hotplate. Approximately 70 have been sold. Testing of a subset of these has revealed substantial error in the determination of wind speed, and thus, in determination of both snow particle catch efficiency and precipitation amount. In this project, a solution to the speed bias problem is investigated. This project aims to establish the applicability of a new speed bias correction for four collocated hotplate systems, the applicability of a new snow particle catch efficiency function based on the corrected wind speed, and that these modifications lead to consistency among the wind and precipitation measurements obtained from the four collocated systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Our objective was to improve the precision and accuracy of precipitation rate measurements, precipitation amount measurements, and wind speed measurements, acquired using a hotplate-type system. The hotplate-type systems we tested (Figure 1) were manufactured by Yankee Environmental Systems (YES; Turners Falls, MA). Another hotplate manufacturer is Pond Engineering (Berthoud, CO).

The company YES has incorporated a microprocessor into their hotplate system. This runs an algorithm which derives the precipitation rate. The YES algorithm is proprietary. Our approach was to start with open-source calibration data, recordings of wind speed, recordings of electric power supplied to a hotplate’s temperature-controlled up-viewing plate, and an equation describing the plate’s energetic steady state. We use these elements to determine precipitation rate and precipitation amount. Peer-reviewed papers which use this method are Fuller et al. (2023; AMT; see literature citation at end of and in the NSF Public Access Repository) and Marlow et al. (2024; JAMC). We also compared values of hotplate-derived wind speeds to values derived using a rotating anemometer (Fuller et al. 2023). Finally, in a manuscript which is in preparation, we compare precipitation values obtained from three collocated hotplates.

The energetic steady state concept, discussed in the previous paragraph, is apparent in many disciplines. The following links provide descriptions of energetic steady states within the disciplines of cloud microphysics and engineering thermodynamics. We are providing these to assist others considering our data processing methodology.

https://doi.org/10.15786/wyoscholar/9859

https://doi.org/10.15786/17161178

The NSF1850809 allowed us to compare precipitation rates and amounts reported by three collocated hotplate systems. We did this for 109 precipitation events recorded at a site located approximately 500 m from the Laramie, WY airport’s Automated Surface Observing System (ASOS). Most of the events classified as snow (N=71; T < oC); others are mixed-phase (N=15, 0 oC < T < 4 oC) and rain (N=33; T > 4 oC). Regardless of hydrometeor phase, the precipitation rates we report have the following dimension: liquid equivalent depth per unit time (mm h-1).

Figures 2a and 2b present, for the snow events, the regression-line slopes derived from the system-versus-system precipitation rate scatterplots (i.e., HP1-vs-HP2, HP1-vs-HP3, and HP2-vs-HP3). The regression lines were forced through the plot origins. Labels in the figures are the dates of the snow events and the number of one-minute samples in the regressions. These figures are a component of the manuscript which is in preparation.

Averaged slopes and standard deviations for the snow events are 1.01±0.11 (HP1 vs HP2), 1.00±0.14 (HP1 vs HP3), and 1.00±0.10 (HP2 vs HP3). For the rain events these are 1.01±0.05 (HP1 vs HP2),  0.96±0.06 (HP1 vs HP3), and 0.95±0.03 (HP2 vs HP3). Larger standard deviation is associated with snow compared to rain. This is a consequence of the smaller averaged precipitation rate in snow (1.1 mm h-1) compared to that in rain (2.4 mm h-1). Slopes corresponding to most of the snow events are constrained between 0.8 and 1.2 (Figures 2a and 2b).

We also compared our measurements to those reported by an Alter-shielded heated tipping bucket gauge. The latter was operated at the ASOS located near our test site (Figure 1). Present weather observations from the ASOS are printed at the top of Figure 3. Also, hourly precipitation amounts are plotted in the figure. The events shown were not associated with narrow precipitation structures that occurred during some of our investigations. Precipitation measurements that were associated with narrow precipitation structures were discarded from comparisons like those shown in Figure 3. This was necessary because the hotplates and ASOS were separated by ~ 500 m. The figure demonstrates that there is reasonable agreement between hotplate-derived and ASOS-derived precipitation amounts and that this agreement is evident for both snow and rain. Not shown is the fact that reasonable agreement was also documented for the HP1-vs-ASOS and the HP2-vs-ASOS comparisons. Figure 3 is a component of the manuscript which is in preparation.

NSF1850809 also supported outreach at the Laramie Middle School (LMS). One example of this was our development of online instructional materials for the LMS. One of those can be accessed here:

https://wyoscholar.uwyo.edu/handle/internal/9663

Two graduate students were involved in NSF1850809. In Fuller et al. (2023), hotplate measurements were analyzed with measurements from a W-band radar. The publication demonstrates that using a W-band reflectivity to infer snowfall rate can lead to underestimation of precipitation amount when the hydrometeor type is rimed snow particles. In Marlow et al. (2024), snow accumulations acquired at a high-elevation site were analyzed. Data from both a sheltered and wind-exposed gauge were compared. This publication demonstrates that the resuspension of surface-derived snow particles can positively bias precipitation amounts acquired at high-elevation sites within the Rocky Mountain region. The two students who collaborated on NSF1850809 are now working for the National Weather Service.

Fuller et al., Atmospheric Measurement Techniques, 2023

Marlow et al., Journal of Applied Meteorology and Climatology, 2024
